scrape.title: The dinner
scrape.author: George
scrape.text: DARK, UGLY & UNPALATABLE.“But a world without disasters and violence—be it the violence of nature or that of muscle and blood—would be the truly unbearable thing.”—page 152One of the unlikable (they’re all unlikable) characters in Herman Koch’s novel, THE DINNER, poses the premise that, with so many “victims” in the history of the world, not all of them, certainly, could have been “innocent.” Surely some of them must have deserved their fate—even worse. And, with just such a rationale, all manner of sick and sadistic idiocy becomes excusable.Recommendation: I’ll give this novel two-stars, but I’ll be damned if there’s anyone to whom I’d recommend it.“But we’re not talking here about civilized people. These are people everyone would be relieved not to have around anymore.”—page 210Adobe Digital [ePub] edition, 238 pages. On loan from: http://overdrive.colapublib.org/
